dc:description:
Primary Ciliary Dyskinesia (PCD) is a genetically heterogeneous group of disorders, usually beginning in early childhood, characterized by chronic cough, recurrent infections of the upper and lower respiratory tract, randomization of left/right body asymmetry, and subfertility (PMID: 32943623). The PCD phenotype results from structural and/or functional abnormalities of motile cilia and flagella. Ciliary motility is powered by a set of axoneme-specific dynein motor complexes. The cytoplasmic assembly of these large multiprotein complexes before their transport into cilia is assisted by dynein axonemal assembly factors (DNAAFs). Mutations in genes encoding DNAAFs result in the improper cytoplasmic preassembly of dynein chains, causing defects in both inner (IDA) and outer dynein arms (ODA) that can result in cilia immotility (PMID: 31624012).
 
In 2017 Paff et al. and Olcese et al. (PMIDs: 28041644, 28176794) described an X-linked non-syndromic PCD caused by mutations in *DNAAF6* (*PIH1D3*) in 12 families. Affected individuals in these families shared a classic PCD phenotype with ciliary and sperm immotility. At the ultrastructural level this PCD was characterized by an absence of ODAs and reduced to absent IDAs. The specific disease entity, Primary Ciliary Dyskinesia 36 is an X-linked primarily recessive disorder (with variable and milder female expression, PMID: 38408845) caused by hemizygous mutation in the *DNAAF6*  gene. Per criteria outlined by the ClinGen Lumping and Splitting Working Group, we found the molecular mechanism and X-linked recessive mode of inheritance to be consistent among unrelated patients, while the phenotypic variability among them appeared to represent a spectrum of disease rather than separate disease entities. Therefore, cases caused by inherited *DNAAF6* variants have been lumped into a single disease entity, Primary Ciliary Dyskinesia 36 (MONDO: 0010517, OMIM # 300991).

Evidence from 14 probands in 7 publications have been included in this curation representing 12 unique variants (2 missense, 4 nonsense, 3 frameshift, 1 splicing, and 2 small deletions (PMIDs: 28041644, 28176794, 32170493, 38051289, 33106461, 38408845, 33635866). Three probands with large multi-gene deletions that include *DNAAF6* were described but not scored (PMID: 28176794). The mechanism of pathogenicity in *DNAAF6* mutations is X-linked loss of function. While most of the reported PCD patients carrying loss of function *DNAAF6* mutations are male, a more recent study has shown that mothers of male patients with *DNAAF6*-related PCD can display PCD airway phenotypes, the severity of which is dependent on their X-inactivation ratio (PMID: 38408845).

The gene-disease association between *DNAAF6* and PCD 36 is supported by gene expression data.  GTEx RNA-seq expression studies in reference human tissues show strong expression of *DNAAF6* in lung, testis, and Fallopian tube (PMID: 23715323). This pattern is consistent with the role that DNAAF6 is thought to play in the assembly of inner and outer dynein arms in respiratory cilia, sperm flagella, cilia in male efferent ducts, and cilia in Fallopian tubes (PMID: 32943623). 
 
The cytoplasmic folding and preassembly of dynein arm proteins into larger complexes takes place in a stepwise manner involving interactions with various DNAAFs (PMID: 32943623), chaperones, and co-chaperones (PMID: 31817850). Yeast two-hybrid screens as well as co-immunoprecipitation assays from human cell culture extracts overexpressing DNAAF6 confirm the interaction of DNAAF6 with DNAAF2 and DNAAF4 (PMID: 28041644), proteins that have also been associated with PCD. DNAAF2, DNAAF4, and DNAAF6 interact as parts of cytoplasmic multi-protein complexes that assemble inner and outer dynein arm components.

Loss-of-function hemizygous *DNAAF6* mutations result in structural defects in respiratory cilia of PCD patients. Transmission Electron Microscopy studies show an absence of inner and outer dynein arms in patient respiratory epithelial cells. Immunofluorescent studies of these cells show an absence or reduction in some of the dynein arm structural proteins (Heavy chains DNAH5 and DNAH9 and intermediate chains DNAI1 and DNAI2 from ODAs and DNALI1 from IDAs) suggesting a defect in the assembly of the dynein arms. Similar results are seen in immunofluorescent studies of patient sperm flagella where DNAI1 and DNAI2 are absent from patient flagellar axonemes (PMID: 28041644). In another study, electron tomography was used to capture different patterns of IDA assembly in the respiratory cells of *DNAAF6*/PCD patients (PMID: 28176794). These analyses show that *DNAAF6* mutations cause a failure of specific dynein components to assemble into IDAs. These data are consistent with DNAAF6 assisting in the cytoplasmic assembly of axonemal dyneins.

Three non-human experimental models have been used to support the gene-disease relationship between *DNAAF6* and PCD 36. In *Drosophila*, ciliary motility is confined to the sensory cilium of mechanosensory neurons (chordotonal neurons) and the sperm flagellum. Flies with Dnaaf6 knockout or knockdown were viable but deaf, uncoordinated and had immotile sperm, signs consistent with ciliary defects. Authors also performed immunofluorescent studies of differentiating chordotonal neurons in pupal antennae. These studies show loss of ODA markers (Dnah5 and Dnal1) and partial loss of IDA markers (Dnali1) as further evidence that Dnaaf6 is required for assembly of dynein arms (PMID: 35873488). PIH1D3-knockout rats re-capitulate most of the phenotypes seen in human patients with *DNAAF6* related PCD. These phenotypes include male infertility due to defects in the assembly of sperm axonemes and cilia in the efferent ducts. PIH1D3 deficient rats also had accumulation of mucus in the upper respiratory tract (primarily nasal cavity), situs inversus, and perinatal hydrocephalus (PMID: 35873488). Similarities between this rat model and human patients extend to molecular phenotypes such as the loss of inner and outer dynein arms in respiratory cells and dysfunctional preassembly and loading of dynein arms in motile cilia. Zebrafish embryos carrying a homozygous *pih1d3* mutation have immotile cilia, leading to abnormal cardiac looping, a deficiency in pronephric fluid flow, the development of pronephric cysts, and abnormal otolith formation. Zebrafish mutants are missing ODAs and IDAs. These phenotypes are consistent with a role for pih1d3 in the preassembly of dynein arms in zebrafish. These phenotypes can be rescued with wild-type zebrafish *pih1d3* and partially rescued with human *PIH1D3* mRNA.

 In summary, there is definitive evidence supporting a gene-disease relationship between variants in *DNAAF6* and Primary Ciliary Dyskinesia 36. This has been repeatedly demonstrated in both research and clinical diagnostic settings, and has been upheld over time. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Motile Ciliopathy GCEP on April 11, 2024 (SOP Version 10).

evidence.dc:description:
NM_173494.2(DNAAF6):c.511C>T (p.Gln171Ter)is a nonsense mutation that is predicted to trigger NMD or at least truncate ~20% of the protein product.   Down-scored for only sequencing one candidate disease gene (Sanger) as opposed to Exome sequencing or Gene Panel sequencing. Also down-scored because son (DC768 II-1)
was already scored.
Western blot  Analysis shows truncated protein

NM_173494.2(DNAAF6):c.489_492del (p.Ile164LeufsTer11) is a frameshift mutation that is predicted to trigger NMD or at least truncate ~23% of the protein product. This truncation would disrupt the conserved carboxy-terminal CS domain.

Expression of GFP-tagged mutant PIH1D3 in HEK293 cells was assessed by western blotting using anti-GFP antibodies and anti-PIH1D3 antibodies and was found to be truncated compared to the WT 214 aa protein.

NM_173494.2(DNAAF6):c.263_268delinsG (p.Ile88ArgfsTer12) is a frameshift mutation that is predicted to trigger NMD or at least truncate ~59% of the protein product. Downscored because variant identified by Sanger sequencing rather than whole genome method

evidence.rdfs:label: Wang Family 2

member.rdfs:label: Wang Family 2 II-2
member.detectionMethod: Whole exome sequencing. Sanger sequencing was targeted to variant region.
member.phenotypeFreeText: Chronic wet cough, sperm flagella lacking inner and outer dynein arms

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Chronic wet cough, sperm flagella lacking inner and outer dynein arms

evidence.rdfs:label: Gardner Family A

member.rdfs:label: Gardner Family A IV-1
member.phenotypeFreeText: Outer and inner dynein arm defects, wet cough, chest x-ray:bilateral, granular opacities
member.previousTestingDescription: Three, independent multigene panels that included 20‐35 PCD‐associated genes and copy number variant analysis failed to reveal a genetic diagnosis of PCD.

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Outer and inner dynein arm defects, wet cough, chest x-ray:bilateral, granular opacities

evidence.rdfs:label: Gardner Family B

member.rdfs:label: Gardner Family B III-2
member.detectionMethod: Candidate testing of the DNAAF6 by Sanger sequencing
member.phenotypeFreeText: wet cough, central bronchial wall thickening, mor- phologic left middle lobe opacities, ODA and IDA defects
member.previousTestingDescription: Two multigene panels of 29‐30 PCD‐associated genes failed to identify pathogenic variants.

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: wet cough, central bronchial wall thickening, mor- phologic left middle lobe opacities, ODA and IDA defects

member.rdfs:label: DC539 II-1
member.detectionMethod: Sanger sequencing to test an additional cohort of 32 independent male patients to identify additional affected families that carried PIH1D3 mutations.

member.rdfs:label: GVA30 II-1
member.detectionMethod: Next-generation sequencing (NGS) of whole exomes of affected individuals from 76 families

member.rdfs:label: DC121 II-1
member.detectionMethod: Authors of this paper used Sanger sequencing to test an additional cohort of 32 independent male patients to identify additional affected families that carried PIH1D3 mutations.

evidence.dc:description: Not enough segregations
evidence.rdfs:label: OP-1899

member.rdfs:label: OP-1899 II-1
member.detectionMethod: 75 PCD-affected individuals were screened with a targeted-exome panel of 310 genes that included 26 PCD associated genes and a subset of candidate genes. Authors focused on nonsynonymous mutations, splice-site substitutions, and indels following an autosomal-recessive and X-linked inheritance pattern. Pedigree analysis and segregation analysis of family OP-1899 showed that the proband has two unaffected family members (OP-1899 II-2, and II-3 ). and that this is a de novo mutation.
member.phenotypeFreeText: Chronic wet cough; Absent inner and outer dynein arms in sperm flagella and respiratory cells shown by immunofluorescent  antibody studies ,  asthenozoospermia, reduced sperm flagellar length (PMID 33635866)

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Reduced inner dynein arms, Chronic wet cough

member.rdfs:label: PCD392 II-1
member.detectionMethod: Next-generation sequencing of a targeted gene panel in affected individuals from 133 families

evidence.dc:description: Not enough segregations
evidence.rdfs:label: PCD-10

member.rdfs:label: PCD-10 II-1
member.detectionMethod: 75 PCD-affected individuals were screened with a targeted-exome panel of 310 genes that included 26 PCD associated genes and a subset of candidate genes. Authors focused on nonsynonymous mutations, splice-site substitutions, and indels following an autosomal-recessive and X-linked inheritance pattern. Sanger sequencing was performed to confirm genotype in proband (PCD-10 II-1) and family members (PCD-10 I-1, PCD-10 II-2, and in one of the alleles of the mother of proband). This Sanger sequencing confirmed an X-linked recessive mode of inheritance for the PCD-10 family.
member.phenotypeFreeText: Not enough cilia for TEM, Chronic wet cough

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Reduced inner dynein arms, Chronic wet cough

evidence.dc:description: NM_173494.2(DNAAF6):c.511C>T (p.Gln171Ter)is a nonsense mutation that is predicted to trigger NMD or at least truncate ~20% of the protein product.   Down-scored for only sequencing one candidate disease gene (Sanger) as opposed to Exome sequencing or Gene Panel sequencing.
NM_173494.2(DNAAF6):c.290G>T (p.Gly97Val) is a missense mutation that is predicted to be "probably damaging" by Polyphen-2.
HEK293 cells were transfected with WT and variant DNAAF6.  Western blot analysis (probed with anti-FLAG antibody) detected no DNAAF6 in cells expressing variant compared to controls.

NM_173494.2(DNAAF6):c.357_363del (p.Val120LeufsTer6) is a frameshift mutation that introduces a novel termination site and appears to trigger NMD. This variant also appears to produce an alternatively spliced transcript that skips exon 6.   Neither transcript appears to produce a protein product based on Western blot analysis.

Authors performed mRNA analysis with cDNA amplification and sequencing to find two altered transcripts: one with the predicted c.357_363del in exon 6 that introduces premature termination in exon 6 (125 aa) and one that is an alternative splice product that skips exon 6 and introduces a premature termination in exon 8 (181 aa). Full length wild type protein is 214 aa.

Authors also performed experiments to assess nonsense-mediated decay (NMD) by growing respiratory cells in presence and absence of cycloheximide to block protein translation and NMD.  In the absence of cyclohexamide, there was a 76% reduction of PIH1D3, in particular the c.357_363del transcript. The exon 6 skipping transcript terminates in the last exon and is though to be insensitive to NMD.

Authors also performed protein analysis on respiratory cell lysates from patients  PCD-10 I-1, PCD-10 II-1, and PCD-10 II-2, and failed to detect PIH1D3 on a western blot probed with antibodies against PIH1D3.

NM_173494.2(DNAAF6):c.397G>T (p.Asp133Tyr) is a missense mutation that is predicted to be "probably damaging" by Polyphen-2. Down-scored for only sequencing one candidate disease gene (Sanger) as opposed to Exome sequencing or Gene Panel sequencing. (Also, son already scored)

NM_173494.2(DNAAF6):c.127G>T (p.Glu43Ter) is a nonsense mutation that is predicted to trigger NMD or at least truncate ~80% of the protein product. This truncated protein is predicted to be missing the conserved carboxy-terminal CS protein interaction domain.

Expression of GFP-tagged mutant PIH1D3 in HEK293 cells was assessed by western blotting using anti-GFP antibodies and was found to be truncated compared to the WT 214 aa protein.  RT-PCR analysis of nasal respiratory epithelial cells, followed by Sanger sequencing found that there was alternate splicing in PCD12 II-1 cells that skipped exon 3 (compared to control). It is possible that an in-frame start codon in exon 4 would produce an alternative truncated protein.

NC_000023.11:g.107218960_107218970del is a deletion (frameshift) variant that is just 5' of the exon 5 donor splice site (NM_173494.2 c.319_329del). This frameshift is predicted to trigger NMD or at least truncate ~50% of the protein product (p.Glu108Valfs12Ter.) The sequence of this deletion is such that it is also possible that this is a splicing variant that disrupts the intron 5 donor site (NM_173494.2 c. 323_332+1del). This could also lead to NMD or a truncated protein product  (p.Glu108fsTer).  This variant was downscored for consanguinity.
HEK293 cells were transfected with WT and variant DNAAF6.  Western blot analysis (probed with anti-FLAG antibody) detected no DNAAF6 in cells expressing variant compared to controls.

NC_000023.11:g.107218959_107218972del is a splicing variant with a 14bp deletion that includes the donor site of exon 5/intron 5. This variant could result in the production of a truncated protein p.Glu108fsTer3.

NM_173494.2(DNAAF6):c.397G>T (p.Asp133Tyr) is a missense mutation that is predicted to be "probably damaging" by Polyphen-2. Down-scored for only sequencing one candidate disease gene (Sanger) as opposed to Exome sequencing or Gene Panel sequencing.
NM_173494.2(DNAAF6):c.355C>T (p.Gln119Ter) is a nonsense mutation that is predicted to trigger NMD or at least truncate 44% of the protein product.
NM_173494.2(DNAAF6):c.332+1G>A is a splice site variant that disrupts the exon5/intron 5 splice site.

NM_173494.2(DNAAF6):c.266G>A (p.Trp89Ter) is a nonsense mutation that is predicted to trigger NMD or at least truncate ~58% of the protein product. This truncated protein is predicted to be missing the conserved carboxy-terminal CS protein interaction domain.

The Genotype-Tissue Expression (GTEx) project has established a resource database and associated tissue bank for the scientific community to study the relationship between genetic variation and gene expression in human tissues. RNA-seq expression studies were performed on 54 reference tissues. Bulk tissue gene expression for DNAAF6 shows the expression of  DNAAF6 in lung, testis, and Fallopian tube. This pattern is consistent with the role DNAAF6 is thought to play in the assembly of inner and outer dynein arms in respiratory cilia, sperm, cilia in male efferent ducts, and cilia in Fallopian tubes.
evidence.rdfs:label: GTEx DNAAF6 gene expression

evidence.dc:description: Pre-assembly of the inner and outer dynein arms into multi-subunit complexes in the cytoplasm is facilitated by a set of proteins called dynein pre-assembly factors (DNAAFs). These DNAAFs are thought to function as co-chaperones that help facilitate the correct folding of dynein chains and subunit assembly (PMID: 31817850). DNAAF2, DNAAF4, and DNAAF6 are part of a cytoplasmic multi-protein complex that assembles inner and outer dynein arm components.
evidence.rdfs:label: Co-immunoprecipitation studies of PIH1D3 with DNAAFs

evidence.dc:description: Pre-assembly of the inner and outer dynein arms into multi-subunit complexes in the cytoplasm is facilitated by a set of proteins called dynein pre-assembly factors (DNAAFs). These DNAAFs are thought to function as co-chaperones that help facilitate the correct folding of dynein chains and subunit assembly (PMID: 31817850). DNAAF2, DNAAF4, and DNAAF6 are part of a cytoplasmic multi-protein complex that assembles inner and outer dynein arm components.
evidence.rdfs:label: Yeast two-hybrid screen with PIH1D3 (DNAAF6) as bait

evidence.dc:description: Loss-of-function PIH1D3 mutations result in structural defects in respiratory cilia of two PCD patients, each carrying a different hemizygous DNAAF6 mutation. An electron tomography based three-dimensional map of the axonemal 96 nm repeat was generated from averaged tomograms of tissue from two different DNAAF6 PCD patients.  G30 V-1 electron tomograms only captured full absence of the whole IDA along with absent N-DRCs (nexin–dynein regulatory complex) and ODAs.  PCD12 I-1 tomograms  captured different patterns of IDA assembly (with ODAs being present in all the imaging). The entire IDA plus N-DRC were either entirely present, entirely absent, or else a partial IDA assembly was seen  IDA dynein subunits f and g specifically fail to assemble). In summary, these analyses show that  PIH1D3 mutations cause a failure of specific dynein components to assemble into IDAs and ODAs
evidence.rdfs:label: Electron tomography

evidence.dc:description: Loss-of-function PIH1D3 mutations result in structural defects in respiratory cilia of two PCD patients, each carrying a different hemizygous DNAAF6 mutation. TEM microscopy shows an absence of inner and outer dynein arms in respiratory cells of both patients. Immunofluorescent studies of these cells shows an absence or reduction in some of the dynein arm structural proteins (Heavy chains DNAH5 and DNAH9 and intermediate chains DNAI1 and DNAI2 from ODAs and DNALI1 from IDAs), suggesting a defect in the assembly of the dynein arms.  Similar results were seen in immunofluorescent studies of patient sperm flagella where DNAI1 and DNAI2  were absent from patient flagellar axonemes.
evidence.rdfs:label: Structural defects in respiratory cilia from DNAAF6 patients

evidence.dc:description: Down-scored because zebrafish model doesn't recapitulate the respiratory phenotypes seen in human patients
Expression of WT PIH1D3 in embryo zebrafish must allow for normal pre-assembly of dynein arms that allows for a corrected motile cilia phenotype.
evidence.rdfs:label: Zebrafish pih1d3 knockout and rescue

evidence.dc:description: Down-scored because cannot fully recapitulate human respiratory phenotypes of PCD.

In Drosophila, ciliary motility is confined to the sensory cilium of mechanosensory neurons (chordotonal neurons) and the sperm
flagellum. Flies with dnaaf6 knock out or knockdown were viable but deaf, uncoordinated and had immotile sperm, signs consistent with ciliary defects.  Human patients with DNAAF6 mutation also have defects in cilia motility and sperm motility.  Like in humans, Drosophila Dnaaf6 proteins play a role in dynein assembly. Authors show molecular evidence that Dnaaf6 is required for assembly of ODAs and a subset of inner dynein arms IDAs (loss of ODA markers (Dnah5 and Dnal1), partial loss of IDA markers (Dnali1).
evidence.rdfs:label: Drosophila CG5048/Dnaaf6 knockdown model

evidence.dc:description: Pih1d3 knockout rats are able to re-capitulate most of the phenotypes seen in patients with DNAAF6 related PCD.  These phenotypes include male infertility due to defects in the assembly of sperm axonemes and cilia in the efferent ductules.  Pih1dr deficient rats also had accumulation of mucus in the upper respiratory tract (primarily nasal cavity), situs inversus, and perinatal hydrocephalus (in general, also seen in mice PCD models).  Unlike in humans, this knockout caused postnatal lethality so more advanced respiratory phenotypes could not be assessed. Similarities between this rat model and human patients extend to molecular phenotypes such as the loss of inner and outer dynein arms in respiratory cells and dynein arm assembly. Like in human patients, depletion of the critical components from ODAs and IDAs (DNAI1, DNAI2, DNALI1) was seen by immunofluorescence staining in respiratory cells, efferent ducts, and brain ependymal cells. Biochemical analysis shows that PIH1D3 interacts with other proteins involved in the assembly and trafficking of ODAs and IDAs (DNAAF2, DNAAF4, DNAAF7,DNAAF8, DNAAF10, IFT52, IFT57, PIH1D1).
evidence.rdfs:label: Rat PIH1D3 knockout model exhibits PCD-like phenotypes

evidence.dc:description: Fails to replicate PCD respiratory and laterality defects.  Mouse pih1d3 is an intronless "pseudogene" version on chr 1 of the gene on chr X.  Knockout of the X-linked mouse version of this gene is likely to provide a stronger model for human PCD.

This model replicates the male infertility phenotypes seen in human PCD  caused by pathogenic variants of PIH1D3 but fails to replicate any of the  other phenotypes that are seen in human PCD patients (respiratory and laterality defects). Twister2 (Pih1h3b), the gene on Chr X, is expressed in various organs with motile cilia, including lung, brain and oviduct so perhaps a Pih1h3b knockout would produce more PCD-like phenotypes. 

This model system suggests a role for PIH1D3 in dynein arm assembly. In mice this role seems to be separated into two functions by different copies of the PIH1D3 gene. The Chr 1 copy plays a role in dylain arm assembly of the sperm axoneme, while the Chr X copy may play a role in other motile cilia. The cilia-expressed X-linked copy is unable to compensate for the Chr 1 copy in sperm. These observations contrast with human data that show that X-linked mutations in the human PIH1D3 gene cause both cilia and sperm defects.
evidence.rdfs:label: Mouse Pih1d3 (chr1) knockout causes sperm flagellar defects
